thread.title: Better Care set to expand across Oz
thread.title_full: Better Care set to expand across Oz

author: Petrina Berry
title: Better Care set to expand across Oz
text:
PETER Scutt became fixed on shaking up the home care industry after struggling to find affordable and suitable support for his elderly parents.
HE endured an agonising search for a long-term carer for his 83-year-old mother, whose dementia was getting worse, and for his frail 91-year-old father, who wanted to continue to live at home with his wife.
"It was expensive, we also had little choice in who the carer was, with up to 20 different carers rotating through the house in a month," he said. "As people age, they want to know who is coming to the door, and so this was a problem." His frustrations with the industry gave birth to the idea of creating an online platform that connects families with local carers and disability support workers, thus cutting out the middleman. "We had this idea of a peer-to-peer network where you can find people locally, contact them directly and allow families to choose a carer," he said. "We also want to make it a more attractive industry to work in by giving carers an opportunity to run their own business, to choose their clients and to choose when and where they work." After two years of solid work, Mr Scutt, and co-founder Tony Charara launched Better Caring in December. The site now has a network of 350 care workers, mainly from New South Wales and more than 1,500 potential carers whose applications are going through the necessary checks, including police records and employer references. He said like many other online marketplaces in other sectors, Better Caring was able to provide more affordable rates. The business has recently scored an extra $2.3 million from investors, including the backing of Tony Wales, co-founder of share registry business Computershare, to expand its service beyond New South Wales and into Victoria and Queensland as it strives to become a national industry player.
